translation.en: [Lynch] That state of simplest form of awareness alone,
is worthy of seeing, hearing, contemplating and realizing."
translation.ko: ‘보고 듣고 생각하고 깨닫는 것에 버금간다’ “데이비드 린치”

translation.en: From the Upanishads.
[Jan] That day, I was going to meet my sister for lunch.
I emailed her that morning, just to confirm what time,
and I didn't hear anything back.
Thinking, "It's really strange how Lotje hasn't got back to me."
You know, because I had also texted, "Are you okay?"
Which is, like, quite a strong, um... message.
And I was sure that she would text back.
translation.ko: 저는 곧 답신이 올 줄 알았습니다

translation.en: [Ant] Usually, you know, she comes into work every day.
She didn't come in on the Monday, and, uh, I thought it was a bit weird.
translation.ko: “앤트 로체의 동료” 월요일에 결근해서 좀 이상하게 생각했죠

translation.en: [Barney] I, um, walked, like, four, five minutes to where her flat was.
And that's where Jan was with Ant,
looking more and more confused by what was going on.
-[Jan] We tried to bang on the door... -[loud knocking] ...shout, but she wasn't responding.
translation.ko: 문 두드리고 소리 질러도 대답이 없었습니다

translation.en: [Barney] I remember Jan kind of calling out, "Lotje!"
What was going through our minds was that
there's only one reason why she'd still be in her flat.
[Jan] At that point, I decided to call 999.
The police arrived together with the landlord, who had a key.
[Ant] And there was this very strange moment of, like,
the police holding Jan back a bit, saying, "Do you want us to go in first?"
The guy who opened the door, not wanting to be the first guy to go in there.
It was all very strange. And Jan just said, "I'm going in."
translation.ko: 기분이 아주 묘했고 얀이 들어간다고 했어요

translation.en: [Jan] The flat just looked like some serious chaos had happened.
translation.ko: 아파트 안은 엄청난 폭풍이 지나간 후 같았어요

translation.en: You know, I was like, "Shit, where is she?"
Everything was topsy-turvy.
There was clothes everywhere, there was vomit
and excrement everywhere.
The fact that she wasn't there was sort of a relief.
But then the next question was, "Where is she?"
[Hente] Lotje's always been quite good at going somewhere, to adventures,
and experiencing-- Going and seeing friends, so...
I've had this throughout my life.
translation.ko: 전 평생 이 말을 달고 살았어요 “헨테 로체의 엄마”

translation.en: "Where is Lotje?" has been a question.
You know, you go to the supermarket
and you pick something from the shelf, "Where is Lotje?"
[Jan] Somebody at Royal London fitted Lotje's description.
translation.ko: 마침 병원에 로체와 비슷한 인상착의의 환자가 있었지만

translation.en: They couldn't identify her, because she wasn't able to speak.
The police that I'd called and the police at the Royal London
translation.ko: 통화한 경찰과 병원에 있던 경찰 덕에

translation.en: managed to, sort of, work out that this was my sister.
translation.ko: 제 동생이란 걸 확인할 수 있었죠

translation.en: [Andrew] To see a young patient who is semi-conscious,
translation.ko: 의식이 어느 정도 있던 젊은 환자가

translation.en: who is actually becoming more unconscious as time goes by,
with the speed that she was deteriorating,
really, you're faced with a situation
where you have to decide to act urgently and save a life.
translation.ko: “앤드루 엘스모어 신경외과의” 신속한 처치가 필요하단 판단을 내렸습니다

translation.en: [Jan] We arrived at the hospital,
where it was explained that Lotje was undergoing some kind of
translation.ko: 로체의 뇌에 아주 심각한 급성 질환이 발생했고

translation.en: very severe medical emergency to her brain.
And that she had a very high probability of... of dying.
She'd had an intracerebral brain hemorrhage.
My initial reaction about this was that this was a very large blood clot
and it was immediately life-threatening.
I must say that a lot of these cases are so severe
that it isn't possible to intervene, or if you do, you are unsuccessful.
The surgery involved an incision on the scalp,
the removal of a small window of bone,
approximately that size,
just a small cut through the brain substance itself
to reveal the blood clot,
and then to remove as much of the blood clot as possible.
Now, that doesn't necessarily mitigate
the damage that's been done by the bleed into the brain.
translation.ko: 출혈로 손상된 뇌를 되살릴 순 없습니다

translation.en: That is damage that is done and can't really be reversed.
The commonest type of stroke is actually an area of the brain
that is starved of oxygen and loses its blood supply.
Lotje's type of stroke is a bleed into the brain substance.
Most of them are caused by either an abnormal blood vessel
translation.ko: 대부분 발육 이상으로 비정상인 혈관을 가졌거나

translation.en: that may be developmental, it can be blood-clotting abnormalities,
translation.ko: 혈액 응고 기능에 이상이 있을 때죠

translation.en: and there are a lot of rare things that can cause it.
There are still some tests to be done later down the line,
but at the moment, we don't have a clear cause for why this happened.
translation.ko: 현재로써는 출혈 원인을 명확히 알 수 없습니다

translation.en: It may well be that we never find one,
and it may well be we never know the cause.
translation.ko: 원인을 영원히 못 밝힐 수도 있어요

translation.en: [Jan] They kept her artificially asleep.
It seemed that they had no idea if they'd even be able to wake her up.
translation.ko: 로체가 깨어날 수 있을지 혹시 깨어나더라도

translation.en: Or if she woke up, what her functions would be.
translation.ko: 정상 기능을 회복할지 의사도 잘 몰랐나 봐요

translation.en: So during that whole 24 hours,
we literally had no idea what the outcome would be.

plate...
place... or something completely different.
We're just not sure.
[Lucy] I was really nervous seeing her.

translation.en: And Jan had kept saying how,

Communication, writing films, writing in general and reading.
translation.ko: 홍보, 영화 관련 글쓰기 원고 쓰기, 책 읽기였어요 “아니타 로체의 친구”

...it's almost obscene that this part, um...
it's affected that part of her brain.
[woman] So, today. It starts today, your holiday.

Mathematical function seems to be impaired.

A concern I have at this stage is,

And that pressure ultimately leads to a situation

[Lotje] If I'm faced with the question, "Who am I?"
I'm someone who has a huge amount of friends,
very hard-working,

translation.ko: 그런데 그 모든 증거가 사라진다면 어떡하죠?

translation.ko: 눈에 이상이 생겼는데 아무도 설명을 안 해줘요

translation.ko: 하지만 오른쪽은 마치 다른 차원 같아요

translation.en: [voice echoing] Vision to an internal space, an inner world.

Whether it's my brain or reality,

translation.ko: 월요일에 두 번 남은 실험을 하려고 연구소에 돌아갔고

translation.en: After my zapping, I went home
and started my one hour of words repetition.
-Bird. -Bird.
I started seeing these flashes of color appearing in front of me.
Lots of color, repetitive flashes, growing bigger and bigger, like...
A hallucinogenic, uncontrollable growth of color.
translation.ko: 환각 상태처럼 제어할 수 없이 번져갔죠

translation.en: I started panicking. Um...
When I thought, "Okay, I have to, uh...
I don't know what's happening, but it feels a little bit like a stroke."
translation.ko: 무슨 일인지 몰라도 쓰러질 때와 비슷했죠

translation.en: It's frightening losing yourself...
being lost in your body.
translation.ko: 내 몸 안에서 내가 길을 잃어요

translation.en: I wasn't, obviously, expecting an epileptic fit. [chuckling]
translation.ko: 뇌전증 발작을 일으킬 거라곤 상상도 못 했죠

translation.en: "Epileptic seizures result from abnormal, excessive,
or hypersynchronous neuronal activity in the brain.
About 50 million people worldwide have epilepsy,
and nearly 90% of epilepsy occurs in the developing countries."
[Lotje] Okay.
-[Hente] Just... just... -I don't have epilepsy.
Do I?
My vision is distorted...
but this time, it isn't interesting like it was in Nov-- November.
translation.ko: 하지만 이번엔 전처럼 멋져 보이는 게 아니라

translation.en: It's scary.
Okay, now I'm seeing things on my right hand side.
-Things that shouldn't be there. -[indistinct voices]
I see this...
phantom... object.
Colors are getting brighter and the patterns keep repeating.
translation.ko: 색은 더 밝아졌고 같은 무늬가 반복해서 보여요

translation.en: Orange. No. Yeah. No, purple.
And green. And they keep growing.
[Hente] "Diplopia, double vision, amnesia, balance disorder,
translation.ko: ‘물체가 둘로 보이는 복시현상 기억상실, 균형감각 이상’

translation.en: disturbance in attention,
loss of concentration, memory impairment."
-[siren wailing] -[Lotje] The land looks unfamiliar.
I feel like a stranger here.
Tomorrow, I'll talk to Elsmore and see what he thinks.
I hope it's not gonna be like this for the rest of my life.
translation.ko: 평생 이렇게 사는 건 아니었으면 좋겠어요

translation.en: -I'm terrified of having... -[baby wailing] ...another epi.
[Hente] "Agitation, depression, emotional instability,
mood swings, hostility or aggression, insomnia,
nervousness, irritability, personal disorders, behavioral problems."
Great medication!
Perfect for your condition, I would say.
Isn't it? [chuckling]
[Andrew] You were telling me that you'd had a seizure.
So, tell me what happened there.
Well, I've been doing this, um, electromagnetic therapy thing.
Uh, I forget what it... See... [stammering] I've regressed.
-I have regressed since the seizure. -Yeah.
Um, but... Um, but yeah, it's, um...
Yeah, some sort of...
-Um, transmagnetic... -Yes, I know what you mean.
I don't have much experience of the technique.
It would not surprise me at all
if it were a potential side effect to the treatment,
translation.ko: 부작용이 생겼대도 크게 놀랄 일은 아니지만

translation.en: but I don't know for definite.
Brain injury puts you at risk of seizures,
so you were at risk of having a seizure with or without the treatment,
translation.ko: 그 치료를 안 받았어도 위험 가능성이 있었어요

translation.en: so, difficult to say, for me, whether it was directly related.
translation.ko: 꼭 그 요법 때문이라고 단정할 순 없죠

translation.en: Did anyone start you on any treatment for that?
-Yeah, I have to take it every day. -Yes.
[Lotje] And it's for people who have epileptic fits.
[Andrew] Yeah.
So, I don't know if that... you know, if that includes me,
because it might just have been a one-off.
I hope it was a one-off.
It's a bit difficult to tell,
but probably the sensible thing for you at the moment is to be on the treatment.
translation.ko: 일단은 약을 계속 먹는 게 좋겠어요

translation.en: Yeah.
And that's... the most likely situation where this won't happen again,
which is, I'm sure, what you would like at the moment.
[voice grows distant] The medication can make people a little bit drowsy
translation.ko: 그 약을 먹으면 나른해질 수 있고

translation.en: and feel not quite themselves. [echoing]
[Lotje] I remember Jan, my brother, saying...
Uh, "Don't worry, you'll be better in a few weeks."
You know, hopefully making that-- making that assumption.
And some people do recover from, um, strokes very quickly.
translation.ko: 실제로 뇌졸중에서 빨리 회복되는 사람도 있는데

translation.en: But, in my case, language-wise, I certainly didn't.
translation.ko: 언어 측면에서 보면 난 아직 멀었어요

translation.en: So, now I'm thinking...
maybe none of... me will recover quickly ever.
translation.ko: 아무래도 빠른 회복은 불가능할 거 같아요

translation.en: Anything can happen at any time to any degree.
translation.ko: 어떤 순간에 어떤 일이 닥칠지 알 수가 없어요

translation.en: Um, so...
I better not have faith in anything.
-[Jan] Here we are, "Provoked seizure." -[Lotje] Here, yeah.
-Did you ask him about provoked seizure? -Yeah.
-And what did he say about that? -He doesn't really know.
You know, Andy Elsmore is a surgeon.
-A brain surgeon. -Okay.
-That's his specialty. -Yeah.
So anything else needs to be referred to other people.
translation.ko: 그래서 수술 외에는 다른 의사를 만나보래

translation.en: In all fairness...
it sounds like you got no answers from him at all.
Well, what kind of answers would you like?
Some answer. Like, "I don't know" is an answer.
Like what?
Like, "Okay, what are these flashes of light I had?"
"Fits." "And should... Should I have been told that they were?"
translation.ko: 발작이 있을 거라고 왜 말 안 했어요?

translation.en: He can't answer those questions.
-Why not? -Because he wasn't there.
He doesn't know anything about it other than what I've told him.
translation.ko: 내가 말한 거 외에는 전혀 상황을 모르시니까

translation.en: And what did he say?
He said, "I don't know."
[Jan] I was unaware actually, myself, that there is a very high risk,
translation.ko: 실은 저도 잘 몰랐습니다 뇌졸중으로 쓰러지고 1년 내에

translation.en: a one-in-five risk pretty much,
of this happening anyway if you've had a hemorrhage,
in the first year after.
So... [sniffles] ...you know...
I should have probably been more prepared for the fact
translation.ko: 뇌전증이 올 수 있다는 걸 알고

translation.en: that this kind of thing could happen.
For some reason, we weren't, I mean, as a family.
And Lotje wasn't either.
[Lotje] I mean, there's no way of knowing. It's just like...
It's just unfortunate.
Well, the thing is, it's likely to have been a provoked seizure, that's the thing,
translation.ko: 아마도 후천적 뇌전증이 맞을 것 같은데

translation.en: but it's just a question of what provoked it.
[Lotje] Yeah.
[Lotje] ...very slowly.
I was doing a lot better,
but now I've gone backwards again since this, uh...
Show me if you can read this.
-This? -Yeah.
[Dr. Afraim] Just take your time. Just...
[Lotje's voice echoing] "John...
Gifford...
was... the... was the..."
[Dr. Afraim] Just remind me again how long the whole thing lasted for.
When did your speech return?
[Jan] Well, the thing is that the actual fits happened in hospital.
-I see. -So it was many, many hours.
It's probably about-- Um, after the fits, Lotje slept.
So by the time she was speaking again, it was nine o'clock in the evening.
[Dr. Afraim] Okay.
Whether the seizures were triggered or made worse by the treatment
is difficult to answer.
-[Jan] I have a question... -[Dr. Afraim] Yes? ...which is, um, the flashes, were they seizures or not?
translation.ko: 하나만 묻죠, 섬광은 발작과 관련이 없나요?

translation.en: -Uh, they're not seizures, per se. -[Jan] Mmm.
translation.ko: 하나만 묻죠, 섬광은 발작과 관련이 없나요? 섬광 자체는 발작 증상이 아니에요

translation.en: I think it may be that the brain was sort of primed.
Uh, you've got, uh, abnormal brain there anyway.
translation.ko: 뇌에 자극이 되기는 했을 겁니다 이미 뇌에 손상이 가 있던 상태니까

translation.en: So it may be they conspired to give rise to what was,
what sounded like a very prolonged seizure.
In a very small proportion of patients,
generalized seizures can carry fatality, actually.
translation.ko: 전신 발작으로 위독한 상태까지 가기도 하고

translation.en: And certainly patients can die,
for example, in their sleep from a seizure.
So, generalized seizures certainly need to be treated.
translation.ko: 전신 발작은 꼭 치료해야 할 질병입니다

translation.en: Here I am on my last visitation to Queen Square.
translation.ko: 오늘 퀸 스퀘어 연구소를 마지막으로 찾았어요

translation.en: Curious to see... [sniffles]
...how much worse... off I am...
than I was...
before the...
the fits set in...
and certainly disturbed and destroyed...
my brain and my mind.
[Dr. Alex] So, this graph...
it turned out that you had the tDCS in the first week.
translation.ko: “단어 읽기 속도” 경두개 전류 자극 첫 주 기록이 있어요

translation.en: 'Cause, remember, we were blinded to that, so we had to, um, unblind ourselves.
And the biggest improvement was, in fact, in the first week.
translation.ko: 가장 크게 개선된 시기가 첫 번째 주였어요

translation.en: So you can see that your reading speeds,
actually for both trained and untrained words,
um, both of them increased dramatically.
-Oh, wow. -Quite dramatically there.
So you've gone from an average of around about 2.2 seconds per word
translation.ko: 단어 하나 읽는 데 평균 2.2초가 걸리다가

translation.en: down to an average of about 1.5 seconds.
That's about 40% improvement in reading speed, something like that.
-Wow. -Yeah.
-So that's quite impressive. -That's great.
-So that is good news. -Thank you.
Well, it's all your hard work, really. And we would predict this.
translation.ko: 열심히 한 덕분이죠 좋은 결과를 예상했어요

translation.en: So, generally speaking, there's a big effect of practice.
But there's a hint here that there's an effect of the tDCS.
Scientifically, it's unfortunate because you had the seizure,
that the last time point would've helped us.
So, if you hadn't had the fit and you had gone down again here,
translation.ko: 발작만 없었다면 좌표가 더 내려갔을 거예요

translation.en: in other words, you'd improved again,
that would've been good evidence that there wasn't a real effect of the tDCS,
translation.ko: 전류의 영향 없이도 회복된다는 좋은 증거인데

translation.en: but because we lost that last time point, we can't really answer that question.
translation.ko: 지난번 기록이 없어 뭐라 말할 수 없네요

translation.en: I'm sorry about that. [chuckling]
It's not your fault. Absolutely not your fault at all.
[Dr. Alex] The data that we got from you, we are very encouraged by.
translation.ko: 로체의 임상시험 자료는 우리에게 큰 도움이 됐어요

translation.en: And we're using this to put together
a grant application to, obviously to do it in more subjects.
So all of this stuff, you know, promising, but not conclusive,
is gonna go into an application to try and do it on a bigger level.
translation.ko: 앞으로 더 다양한 연구로 치료법을 개선해 나가야겠죠

translation.en: [Lotje] Did I understand correctly that, um...
you're not going to be testing any more zapping on brain hemorrhage people?
translation.ko: 뇌졸중 환자에게는 더 이상 실험을 안 한단 건가요?

translation.en: [Dr. Alex] Yeah, I think we'll...
We'll probably put that in as one of the exclusion criteria.
Obviously, we want to be safe, but on the other hand,
if you exclude a load of people in these studies,
then when you finally publish it, um...
there will be no evidence for a certain proportion.
So I'm always a little bit wary about excluding people,
translation.ko: 그래서 대상을 제외할 때 굉장히 신중하게 접근해요

translation.en: because as soon as you start excluding a certain type of person,
it then means that whatever you find cannot be generalized to those people.
translation.ko: 동종 환자들에게는 이 치료법을 쓸 수 없으니까

translation.en: Okay. I wouldn't want to be, you know...
I wouldn't want to contribute to people missing out
on potentially helpful treatment.
But, um... But, yeah, at the same time...
-Uh, well, it's not... -...having a fit isn't fun.
It's not really a decision for you or a decision for me.
There's a group of us, and, ultimately, it's down to the ethics committee.
translation.ko: 다 같이 고민해봐야 하고 윤리위원회 심의를 통해

translation.en: So they decide what is safe and what isn't.
I mean, if there is a safety issue, then, surely it's a good thing to exclude those.
translation.ko: 안전상 문제가 있다면 저 같은 환자를 제외해야죠

translation.en: [clicks tongue] I think it's something that we're all discussing.
-Yeah. -Okay.
[Jan] Okay, so it didn't work. Is that what you're hearing?
[Lotje] No, it did work, there's a 60--
There's 40% increase of improvement in the first week.
[Jan] Okay, I can't read this, then. Can you explain it to me?
translation.ko: 난 이 도표 못 읽겠다 설명 좀 해줘

translation.en: [Lotje] Do you see... Do you see...
I mean, to be honest, I have no fucking idea.
translation.ko: 솔직히 말할게 나도 뭔 소린지 몰라

translation.en: [Jan] So basically, if the red line--
[Lotje] There's a 40% increase in the first week,
and then it flatlines out.
[Lotje] It terrifies me that death can just spring up out of nowhere,
translation.ko: 갑자기 발작이 일어나서 죽어버리는 건 아닐까

translation.en: and, um, threaten to take me away.
I mean, that could happen to anybody at any time.
translation.ko: 언제, 누구에게나 생길 수 있는 일이잖아요

translation.en: [Lotje] My first holiday since my brain was broken
with the magical Miss Lucy McRae.
This is undoubtedly the cure.
The brain needs to be quiet to perform its function.
translation.ko: 뇌 기능을 되찾기 위해선 침묵이 필요했어요

translation.en: Quiet.
I feel much closer to my consciousness,
a much more raw closeness to the self
that is the essence of me.
If the physical body, the brain, is damaged,
does this extend to damage to the self?
I need to be comfortable with... with subtle,
or some may say "unsubtle" differences
translation.ko: 미묘할 수도 있고 확연할 수도 있는 변화에

translation.en: between who I was before and who I am now.
In meditation, I've discovered the fragility of the mind
translation.ko: 명상을 통해 깨지기 쉬운 내 정신과

translation.en: and also its limitless resources.
And in that discovery, I've become empowered.
The silence, solitude.
[chuckling, speaking French] Ah, it's me.
-[Lotje speaks French] Is it your garden? -Yes.
It's very peaceful here, there's no noise.
I'm here every day and there's no noise. Apart from when I'm on my tractor.
translation.ko: 매일 나와봐도 내 트랙터 소리 말곤 적막강산이요

translation.en: Yes, I mean, the tractor makes noise. Or when I use the trimmer...
To cut the grass.
But otherwise there's no noise.
[Lotje] No.
[Lotje speaking English] Just breathe.
Don't panic. Let go of fear.
Okay. I hope to be able to share with you
some insights from my own recovery of, um, my intracerebral brain hemorrhage.
translation.ko: 회복하면서 깨달은 것들을 이 자리에서 나누고 싶어요 “인지 의사소통 학회 런던”

translation.en: Cognition seems a very complex and mysterious thing, um,
translation.ko: 제 뇌와 씨름하면서 인지란 대단히 복잡하고

translation.en: that I've tried to get my own head around.
So I hope I can share some of those insights with you,
translation.ko: 제가 깨달은 것들을 여기서 공유하고 싶은데

translation.en: but I'm not sure if I can. [chuckling]
Um, I think one of the challenges, probably, for therapists is to...
to just deal with the fact that you...
you know, you have to work with somebody who is being assessed
and somebody who is being defined by their limitations,
because that's the only way to figure out how to make them better.
And I think just the experience of, sort of, continually being defined by
translation.ko: 환자로선 능력이 떨어지고 한계가 있는 사람이란 걸

translation.en: what you can no longer do, or how you're sort of limited,
becomes, I think, devastating.
Is there anything that you could advise us, as therapists, um...
to help you get through that?
Or do you think there was no other way that we could have done it,
but said it like it was?
To maybe focus on things that a patient might find along the way.
[stammering] Where they're always, um, initially defined by what they can't do,
translation.ko: 환자들은 처음부터 뭘 못하게 됐다는 말만 들어요

translation.en: they may discover something that they weren't expecting at all,
translation.ko: 하지만 아무도 예상 못 한 결과를 얻을 수도 있죠

translation.en: which is certainly what happened in my case.
Dear Mr. Lynch:
My name is Lotje Sodderland.
Almost exactly a year ago, I had a brain hemorrhage.
It doesn't feel like a year,
'cause time has taken on a different dimension.
I was trying to relearn my reading faculty with a therapist.
And something struck me in those words
that completely changed my experience of recovery.
translation.ko: 투병생활이 완전히 새로워졌어요 “모든 인간은 진정한 행복의 바다와” “의식, 지성, 창조력 사랑을 품고 있다”

translation.en: I've learnt that I'm strong,
but I've also accepted my vulnerability.
I've learnt to focus only...
on what matters.
It just takes a very long time...
to get used to a new brain.
[recorded male voice] Please find attached the tenancy agreement.
Please initial each page where prompted.
[Lotje] I don't need to return to my old life.
This is a new existence, a new dynamic,
where I wasn't defined by my limitations,
but rather about endless possibility.
Thank you, Mr. Lynch.
A really, really important part of this story has been this film.
translation.ko: 이 영화는 내 치료과정에서 정말 중요한 역할을 했어요

translation.en: The film was something that was absolutely born of necessity.
translation.ko: 오로지 필요에 의해 찍게 된 영상이었는데

translation.en: It's created a way for me to understand something that's extremely complex,
translation.ko: 극도로 복잡한 나의 상태를 이해할 길을 열어주었고

translation.en: and it's created a structure.
Yeah, a narrative structure for me to understand my own story.
translation.ko: 맞아요, 내 사정을 이해하기 위한 기승전결이죠

translation.en: Happy face.
We don't really know the answers.
But what I can say in this second of existence,
reality...
is only...
what we believe and perceive to be true.
translation.ko: 우리가 확신하고 따르는 진실에 있다는 걸

translation.en: That makes absolute sense to me.
And very little does these days.
Everybody loves a story. And this is a really good one.
translation.ko: 다들 이야기를 좋아하죠 내 이야기는 진짜 재미있어요

translation.en: With a beginning and a very long middle, and it will have an end.
translation.ko: 발단이 있고 긴 전개에 이어 결국엔 끝이 나죠

translation.en: The story will have an end. The experience probably won't.
translation.ko: 이 이야기는 끝나지만 내 경험은 계속돼요

translation.en: Hi, David. My name's Lotje Sodderland.
translation.ko: 안녕하세요, 린치 감독님 제가 로체 소더랜드예요

translation.en: Are you Lotje Sodderland? -I am. -[audience laughing]
Lotje, it's so good to hear your voice.
I can't see you, Lotje, but I wanna say, I loved your video letter to me.
translation.ko: 얼굴은 안 보이지만 영상편지는 참 잘 봤어요

translation.en: And I'm very happy, as I told you,
that you found meditation
and you're enjoying it and enjoying the benefits.
So, uh, what was your question you'd like to ask tonight, Lotje?
translation.ko: 오늘 밤에 하고 싶은 얘기는 뭔가요?

translation.en: I wanted to thank you, first of all, for inviting me this evening,
but also for transforming my, um...
um, my experience.
Not only of a very sort of devastating brain injury recovery,
translation.ko: 저는 절망적인 중증 뇌 손상뿐만 아니라

translation.en: but also of my sort of perception of existence.
And, um... And my question to you was,
do you think the brain is the engine of the mind or vice versa?
translation.ko: 뇌는 정신의 엔진일까요? 아니면 그 반대일까요?

translation.en: They say consciousness is the driver of everything.
translation.ko: 의식이 인간의 모든 것을 이끈다고들 말하죠

translation.en: The brain is a beautiful thing.
And now with brain research, they can see on the EEG machine
translation.ko: 뇌 연구 결과에 따르면 뇌파 검사를 할 때

translation.en: that when a person truly transcends, they see a wondrous thing.
translation.ko: 모든 걸 초월한 인간의 뇌에선 경이로운 현상이 보인대요

translation.en: Boom! The full brain lights up. They call it "total brain coherence."
translation.ko: 전체가 밝게 빛나는 현상으로 ‘전체 뇌 일관성’이라 하는데

translation.en: And it's the only experience in life that does that.
That coherence gets more and more permanent,
giving rise to higher states of consciousness,
and ultimately supreme enlightenment, which is total fulfillment,
total liberation,
a state they describe as "more than the most,"
living totality.
